headline: Arizona governor won't say transgender people exist
sentences: Governor Ducey defended the legislation that bars transgender girls and women from playing on girls' high school and women's college sports teams and barring gender-affirming surgery for anyone under age 18.
"I'm going to ask you to read the legislation and to see that the legislation that we passed was in the spirit of fairness to protect girls' sports in competitive situations," Ducey said.
A reporter asked Ducey if there "are really transgender people," and the governor answered that the new law indeed targets transgender girls who want to play on girls' sports teams.
The answer shocked the Arizona director of the Human Rights Campaign, a national civil rights group that advocates for equality for LGBTQ people, Bridget Sharpe.
Meanwhile, the top Democrat in the state House, Rep. Reginald Bolding, called Wednesday "probably one of the darkest days we've seen in the history of Arizona."
The reporter insisted and asked again if he believed that there are "actual transgender people," Ducey dodged the question again.
"It's quite shocking that he can't even address trans people or even say that he thinks they exist," Bridget Sharpe said.
Ducey dodged two direct questions about the topic a day after he signed legislation attacking transgender rights.
